case_name: Devilal Modi v. Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 249 of 1964 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 29, 1963, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 129 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 249 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 29, 1963, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 129 of 1963. M. Trivedi, R. C. Koohatta, S. C. Dafria, S. S. Khanduja, K. Manchanda and Ganpat Rai, for the appellant.

facts.text: The appellant Devilal Modi is the Proprietor of M/s. Daluram Pannalal Modi.

anchor.surface_text: writ petition filed by the appellant Devilal Modi, who is the Proprietor of M s. Daluram Pannalal Modi, under Art. 226 of the Constitution. The appellant has been assessed to sales- tax for the year 1957-58 under the Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, 1950.

facts.text: The appellant was assessed to sales-tax for the year 1957-58 under the Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has been assessed to sales- tax for the year 1957-58 under the Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, 1950. He challenged the validity of the said order of assessment by a writ petition filed by him  No. 114/1961  in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh on the 25th April, 1961.

facts.text: The appellant filed writ petition No. 114/1961 in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh on April 25, 1961 challenging the assessment order.

anchor.surface_text: He challenged the validity of the said order of assessment by a writ petition filed by him  No. 114/1961  in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh on the 25th April, 1961. The High Court dismissed his writ petition and by special leave, the appellant came to this Court in appeal against the said decision of the High Court.

facts.text: The Madhya Pradesh High Court dismissed the first writ petition No. 114/1961.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed his writ petition and by special leave, the appellant came to this Court in appeal against the said decision of the High Court. On the 8th March, 1963, the appellants appeal by special leave was dismissed by this Court.

facts.text: The Supreme Court dismissed the appellant's appeal by special leave against the High Court's decision on March 8, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On the 8th March, 1963, the appellants appeal by special leave was dismissed by this Court. Thereafter, the appellant filed the present writ petition in the same High Court on the 23rd April, 1963  No. 129/1963 .

facts.text: The appellant filed the second writ petition No. 129/1963 in the Madhya Pradesh High Court on April 23, 1963 challenging the same assessment order.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellant filed the present writ petition in the same High Court on the 23rd April, 1963  No. 129/1963 . By this writ petition the appellant challenges the validity of the same order of assessment.

facts.text: The Madhya Pradesh High Court dismissed the second writ petition on April 29, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has companysidered the merits of the additional grounds urged by the appellant on this occasion and has rejected them. In the result, this second writ petition filed by the appellant has been dismissed by the High Court on the 29th April, 1963.

facts.text: The Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, 1950 was repealed by the Madhya Pradesh General Sales Tax Act, 1958 on April 1, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, 1950, under which the impugned order of assessment against the appellant to pay sales-tax for the year 1957-58 has been passed, was repealed by the Madhya Pradesh General Sales Tax Act, 1958 on the 1st April, 1959.

facts.text: A notice was issued to the appellant by the Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax on December 31, 1960 under the 1958 Act for escaped assessment for 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: It was on the 31st December, 1960 that a numberice was issued to the appellant by the Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax under the 1958 Act. This numberice recited that the Assistant Commissioner was satisfied that the appellants sales during the period from 1-4-1957 to 31- 3-1958 had escaped assessment

facts.text: Fresh assessment proceedings started against the appellant for sales in 1957-58 resulting in order on March 31, 1961 imposing additional tax of Rs. 31,250 and penalty of Rs. 15,000.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this numberice, fresh assessment proceedings were started against the appellant in respect of the sales in the year 1957-58, and as a result of the said proceedings, an order was passed on the 31st March, 1961, imposing an additional tax on the appellant to the extent of Rs. 31,250 for the year in question and a penalty of Rs. 15,000.

facts.text: This order of March 31, 1961 is the subject-matter of both writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: It is this order which is the subject-matter of both the writ petitions. In his first writ petition, the appellant had substantially raised two companytentions.

facts.text: Sales during 1-4-1957 to 31-3-1958 had escaped assessment.

anchor.surface_text: This numberice recited that the Assistant Commissioner was satisfied that the appellants sales during the period from 1-4-1957 to 31- 3-1958 had escaped assessment and thereby the appellant had rendered himself liable to be reassessed under s. 19 1  of the Act.

facts.text: Earlier assessment under 1950 Act was cancelled by order under s. 39(2) of 1958 Act.

anchor.surface_text: the same companyld number be reassessed under the subsequent Act. It is true that the said earlier assessment had been subsequently cancelled by an order made under s. 39 2  of the Act of 1958 but it was argued that the said order of cancellation was itself invalid.

facts.text: In first writ petition, appellant contended delegation under S.30 was invalid as it delegated powers not duties.

anchor.surface_text: He had urged that though S. 30 of the Act had made provision for the delegation of the duties of the Commissioner, in fact by his order passed by the Commissioner in pursuance of the said authority, he had delegated to the Assistant Commissioner his power under S. 19, but number his duties

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected the two contentions in the first writ appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Both these companytentions were rejected by this Court, with the result that the appeal preferred by the appellant was dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Appellant sought to raise two additional points in SC appeal but was not permitted.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that at the hearing of the appeal before this Court, Mr. Trivedi for the appellant sought to raise two additional points, but he was number permitted to do so on the ground that they had number been specified in the writ petition filed before the High Court and had number been raised at an earlier stage.

facts.text: First additional point: sales of sugar not chargeable under S.19(1) of 1958 Act.

anchor.surface_text: The first of these two points was that under S. 19 1  of the 1958 Act only those sales companyld be reassessed which were chargeable to tax under that Act and the sales brought to tax under the impugned order were in respect of sale of sugar, a companymodity the sale of which was number chargeable under the Act.

facts.text: Second additional point: penalty under s.14 of 1950 Act illegal as not saved by s.52 of 1958 Act.

anchor.surface_text: The other point was that the penalty which had been imposed against the appellant by the impugned order under s. 14 of the Act of 1950 was illegal inasmuch as the said Act had been repealed and the right to impose a penalty under it had number been saved by the saving section 52 of the 1958 Act.

facts.text: High Court in second writ petition considered and rejected the additional grounds on merits.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has companysidered the merits of the additional grounds urged by the appellant on this occasion and has rejected them. In the result, this second writ petition filed by the appellant has been dismissed by the High Court on the 29th April, 1963.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal against second writ dismissal is Civil Appeal No. 249 of 1964 by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decision that the appellant has companye to this Court by special leave and that raises the question as to whether it is open to the appellant to challenge the validity of the same order of assessment twice by two companysecutive writ petitions under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: The other point was that the penalty which had been imposed against the appellant by the impugned order under s. 14 of the Act of 1950 was illegal

issues.text: The short question which this appeal raises for our decision is whether the principle of constructive res judicata can be invoked against a writ petition filed by the appellant Devilal Modi, who is the Proprietor of M s. Daluram Pannalal Modi, under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgement of the Court was delivered by Gajendragadkar C.J. The short question which this appeal raises for our decision is whether the principle of companystructive res judicata can be invoked against a writ petition filed by the

issues.text: is it permissible to the appellant to attack the validity of the same order imposing a sales-tax and penalty on him for the year 1957-58 by two consecutive writ petitions ? In other words, is the principle of constructive res judicata applicable to writ petitions of this kind or not ?

anchor.surface_text: The present writ petition raises these two contentions and as we have already indicated, the High Court has examined them on the merits and has rejected them. That is how the question which arises for our decision is, is it permissible to the appellant to attack the validity of the same order imposing a sales-tax

Even if the said orders are passed under the same provisions of law, it may theoretically be open to the party to contend that the liability being recurring from year to year, the cause of action is not the same

anchor.surface_text: In his first writ petition, the appellant had substantially raised two contentions. anchor.surface_text: The short question which this appeal raises for our decision is whether the principle of constructive res judicata can be invoked against a writ petition filed by the appellant Devilal Modi, who is the Proprietor of M s. Daluram Pannalal Modi, under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Res judicata based on public policy: finality of judgments and no relitigation

anchor.surface_text: The general principle underlying the doctrine of res judicata is ultimately based on considerations of public policy. One important consideration of public policy is that the decisions pronounced by courts of competent jurisdiction should be final, unless they are modified or reversed by appellate authorities

arguments.claim: Even constructive res judicata founded on public policy; prevents successive petitions with new grounds

anchor.surface_text: and the other principle is that no one should be made to face the same kind of litigation twice over, because such a process would be contrary to considerations of fair play and justice, vide Daryao and Others v. The State of U.P. Others. It may be conceded in favour of Mr. Trivedi that the rule of constructive res judicata

arguments.claim: Second writ barred by constructive res judicata; allows endless challenges otherwise, against public policy

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the second writ petition filed by the appellant in the present case is barred by constructive res judicata. The result is, the appeal fails and is, dismissed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court upholds via res judicata

holdings.text: the second writ petition filed by the appellant in the present case is barred by constructive res judicata

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the second writ petition filed by the appellant in the present case is barred by constructive res judicata. The result is, the appeal fails and is, dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Successive writ petitions under Art. 226 challenging same assessment order on new grounds barred to uphold public policy of finality, prevent endless litigation, and ensure no relitigation of same cause; even for fundamental rights claims.

holdings.text: it would not be right to ignore the principle of res judicata altogether in dealing with writ petitions filed by citizens alleging the contravention of their fundamental rights

anchor.surface_text: As we have already mentioned, though the courts dealing with the questions of the infringement of fundamental rights must consistently endeavor to sustain the said rights and should strike down their unconstitutional invasion, it would not be right to ignore the principle of res judicata altogether in dealing with writ petitions filed by citizens alleging the contravention of their fundamental rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public policy of finality and fair play applies to writ jurisdiction; cannot allow repeated challenges to same order merely because fundamental rights invoked.

holdings.text: In regard to orders of assessment for different years, the position may be different

anchor.surface_text: In regard to orders of assessment for different years, the position may be different. Even if the said orders are passed under the same provisions of law, it may theoretically be open to the party to contend that the liability being recurring from year to year, the cause of action is not the same

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recurring annual liability creates distinct causes of action per year; constructive res judicata not applicable across years, distinguishing Amalgamated Coalfields.

holdings.text: the rule of constructive res judicata which is pleaded against him in the present appeal is in a sense a somewhat technical or artificial rule prescribed by the Code of Civil Procedure... but basically, even this rule is founded on the same considerations of public policy

anchor.surface_text: It may be conceded in favour of Mr. Trivedi that the rule of constructive res judicata which is pleaded against him in the present appeal is in a sense a somewhat technical or artificial rule prescribed by the Code of Civil Procedure. This rule postulates that if a plea could have been taken by a party in a proceeding between him and his opponent, he would not be permitted to take that plea against the same party in a subsequent proceeding which is based on the same cause of action but basically, even this rule is founded on the same considerations of public policy,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Though artificial (from CPC s.11), constructive res judicata grounded in public policy against successive litigation on same cause; extends to writs to prevent new grounds in repeated petitions.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already mentioned, though the courts dealing with the questions of the infringement of fundamental rights must consistently endeavor to sustain the said rights and should strike down their unconstitutional invasion, it would not be right to ignore the principle of res judicata altogether in dealing with writ petitions filed by citizens alleging the contravention of their fundamental rights.
